title: Give England a fair deal or the United Kingdom could be gone, says UKIP leader Paul Nuttall

The United Kingdom is in danger of breaking apart unless people in England get a fairer deal, UKIP leader Paul Mr Nuttall has claimed. He called for the creation of an English Parliament , to match the parliaments and assemblies in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. 
Mr Nuttall was speaking to the Sunday Sun as the party launched its campaign for the 2017 general election on June 8, when it hopes to make gains in the North. 
The House of Commons at Westminster should become a “Union chamber” dealing with issues such as defence and foreign policy, he said. 
“If the Union’s going to survive into the middle of this century then we’re going to have to have a fully federal UK.” 
He added: “When devolution happened, Scotland got its own Parliament, Wales had its own assembly and Northern Ireland got [the assembly at] Stormont, but the English never truly got anything.” UKIP leader Paul Nuttall (Photo: PA) 
He called for “an English parliament, A Scottish Parliament, a Welsh and a Northern Ireland assembly, and we have a Union chamber as well which deals with issues such as defence and foreign policy.” 
UKIP would scrap HS2 , the high speed rail line due to link London, Birmingham, Manchester and Leeds, and spend the money on local transport schemes instead, said Mr Nuttall. 
And he predicted HS2 would simply suck jobs out of other cities and into London. 
Critics have attacked the line because it misses the North East, heading north from Birmingham but stopping at Leeds. 
Mr Nuttall said: “If you look at studies across she globe, whenever high speed rail connects a smaller city to the capital city, the smaller city always suffers. Read More 
“Because many of these companies have subsidiary companies in these smaller cities and they simply close them down, and all of the business moves to the capital city. 
“HS2 is all about London. It’s all there for the benefit of one place. 
“It’s a vanity project which I predict will cost taxpayers around £100 billion.” 
He stood unsuccessfully in the Stoke Central by-election in February, but his campaign ran into difficulties when it emerged claims had appeared on his website which were untrue. 
This included a claim that he lost close friends in the Hillsborough disaster in 1989. UKIP leader and candidate Paul Nuttall leaves the polling station after voting in the Stoke Central by-election on February 23, 2017 in Stoke-on-Trent (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Mr Nuttall said he had concluded he could not quit as party leader following the defeat because of the damage it would inflict on UKIP. 
Referring to the intense criticism he received in the campaign, he said: “It was difficult. It was pretty hard to take. 
“Not checking the website was my own fault. But that’s all it was, and I think a lot of it got blown out of all proportion. And the whole focus of the country’s political media in a way fell on my shoulders for over two weeks. 
“But in a way it made me stronger really. Read More 'Despicable': Football fan who witnessed Hillsborough tragedy gives verdict on Paul Nuttall 
“Because I knew if it broke me and I thought ‘okay I’ve had enough, I’m just going to walk away from this, I don’t need this’, then actually UKIP was in serious trouble. 
“So I wouldn’t let it break UKIP. I wouldn’t let it break me. And I knew I had a job to do afterwards, which was to restructure and rebuild the party and get it ready for this post-Brexit era.” 
Mr Nuttall became known for dressing in tweed during the by-election. 
He said this was how he usually dressed when he was not wearing an ordinary suit inside the European Parliament. 
“I have always dressed like that. For years. 
"The only difference is, when you see me in Brussels you only ever see me inside, in front of a camera, in the European Parliament where I look pretty ridiculous. 
“In fact, even more ridiculous than I did wearing my tweed jacket and my flat cap. 
“But I’ve always dressed like that.” 
Asked where he bought his tweed jackets, he said: “Different places. Some online and some in shops. 
“But I do like my tweed.” Like us on Facebook
